text: <http://www.fastcodesign.com/3029400/why-nike-is-probably-killing-off-the-fuelband?partner=newsletter&utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&utm_content=5061145>

attachments.title: Why Nike Is (Probably) Killing Off The FuelBand
attachments.text: Why wait for Apple to kill a bad product when you can team up instead?
attachments.fallback: Co.Design: Why Nike Is (Probably) Killing Off The FuelBand

text: oh fast company - you're so silly
did anyone else see that Secret post that was put up last week about this?
yeah, not silly
Nike fired most of its wearables dept on friday
it's amazing to me the extent to which publications took this news and then extrapolated all sorts of bizarre narratives around it
and i have a friend in Digital Sport that confirmed
oh yeah - I mean, the layoffs are real
Yes, saw this a lot over the weekend
I think the rational publications are building off that are what's silly
Makes perfect sense since hardware isn't Nike biz and they don't seem to make a lot $ from this.
right. i think their read on it is probably pretty accurate tho
see - here's what I have a hard time with: Nike IS in the hardware biz. They understand at a profound level the manufacturing process. to the level they build one off shoes on a mass scale
yeah, there are differences, but they're not so different that Nike couldn't learned from them
but theyre not an electronics company
i think their biggest struggle is with the software part of things
yeah - I think software is much harder for them
my guess is that as much as anything they're looking at this market and realizing that there isn't a lot of profit to be made
which is why I think Apple is going to sit it out for a while
my guess is that iWatch isn't a 2014 thing

and I don't think Nike's approach to wearables had anything do with them canning the fuelband. The notion that Fuelpoints was somehow too inscrutable for people is counter to every bit of research there is

This is obviously anecdotal, but the more I talk to friends/family the more I hear that they bought all these wearables for their novelty. Mostly everybody is going back to their phones instead of using yet another device they need to charge and take care of.
Yeah - I think THATS the biggest challenge for the wearables industry: figuring out why any one would want to wear one in the first place
which I think is the key bit of strategic rationale missing when people talk about an iWatch
that said - I lost $20 on a bet about the launch date of the iphone, so what do I know
i think we should do a wearables update
*Wearables report update
to first off highlight — when not explicitly part of a study, X number of people just outright stopped using these things
of the people that stuck around, here's what's going on now
to get to that very point that <@U02618EV1> is bringing up
interesting
so when we say "x number of people just stopped using these things" that number is "all of them"
:wink:
I think marce made it longest, and I still use my phone and the fitbit app to track stuff, but yeah, I don't think a single person continues to wear theres
i wear mine
but i haven't synced it in over a week
oh hey
Derick
oh and I think Dave still wears his
though both of you wore them before we started if I remember right
yeah, we both wore the UP
i definitely don't sync/check my stats daily. i do however remember to keep it charged.
also - speaking of wearables: I love this headline: <http://www.dcrainmaker.com/2014/04/pinnacle-samsungs-activity.html>

attachments.title: The Pinnacle of Fitness Failure: Samsung’s Gear Fit Activity Tracker
attachments.text: On Friday I unboxed and got all set Samsung’s Gear Fit activity tracker.  This is the company's first direct attempt &helip;
attachments.fallback: DC Rainmaker: The Pinnacle of Fitness Failure: Samsung’s Gear Fit Activity Tracker

text: it's been interesting to see how consistently Samsung has failed in the wearable space
they're really really bad at this
sorry - was away.
well - maybe that's the wearables update
there's a steep fucking edge
interesting stat that I think may shed light on Nike's thoughts towards wearables: 1 billion smart phones were shipped in 2013 compared to 100 million wearables
100 million is a tiny number when you have to split that between like 5 or 6 companies
some interesting stats in this article: <http://responsive.org/2014/04/nike-and-the-future-of-the-fuelband/#more-353>

attachments.title: Nike and The Future of the Fuelband
attachments.text: Late Friday, CNET reported that Nike had made the decision to turn away from wearable hardware: Nike is gearing up to shutter its wearable-hardware efforts, an
attachments.fallback: Responsive.org: Nike and The Future of the Fuelband

text: "The entire wearable market in 2013 was worth $330 million. Nike makes that much money from a single shoe release."
yeah - I think as much as anything that was the catalyst
that said - I think it's also a sign of a lack of vision from leadership at Nike
agreed.
Yes. It feels more like Fuel Band is to Nike what Apple TV is to Apple. A cool "hobby" that gained more traction than expected.
My only experience at Nike was in ID, so that's all I really know about - but I know that there the capacity for really innovative thinking was huge
I think the disconnect is that Nike gets ID because it's about shoes.
but I think they need to understand the relationship between humans and technology way more than currently do and its difficult to build that sort of institutional knowledge from the outside in
thats why they don't outsource the design of their shoes
any way - I think bowing out of tech because wrist-worn wearables was the answer is pretty short sighted
its funny that that article is really sneaky ploy for undercurrent to grab some of the vacuum this will leave at Nike
yeah, i ignored a lot of that
it was such an awkward transition right at the end
it's like pulling up to a car accident, loudly lamenting the state of auto safety and then mentioning that you sell coffins
hah.
clearly i got link-sharing happy when reading that article. i shared it immediately after reading that line about how much the wearables market was worth.
well - it was an interesting article
it was just that last paragraph
still worth a share I'd say
though - it makes me read parts of it in a slightly different light
